paragraphs.text: More immigration and population growth? London can take it.
paragraphs.label: title

paragraphs.text: Listen to the doomsayers, the scaremongers and the Farage brigade, and you would be forgiven for thinking that London is full
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Our capital, just like our country, they say, can't cope with any more people
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Everything from traffic jams to NHS waiting times is blamed on immigrants
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The only answer, they tell us, is to pull up the drawbridge and close our borders, turning our back on the globalised world that this country did so much to create
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: How, then, do they explain the fact that, according to forecasts, only today will London's population surpass that of 1939 - topping 8.6 million for the first time?
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: It is a stark rebuttal of the frequently peddled myth that says London must stop growing
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Instead of the huge influx of immigrants that headlines wrongly report, in reality the capital's population has only gradually been creeping back to the level of 75 years ago, before the blitz destroyed many parts of the city
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Today, though, shows more than just the falsity of the immigration scare stories
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: it highlights the huge success of London as a city
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Our capital continues to attract people from all over the country and all over the globe because of the opportunities it offers
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: to find work, set down roots, enjoy a world-class cultural scene and be accepted regardless of who you are and where you come from
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: That success should be a cause of great celebration, not something to curse and try to curtail
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: But no one should deny the pressures that come with a growing population
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: - pressures that are particularly acute in the capital
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: London is in the midst of the deepest housing crisis in decades
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: as
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: average house prices soar to 14 times the average salary and rents rise uncontrollably
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: The city's transport system is struggling to cope with demand, with commuters crammed into conditions in which it would be illegal to transport livestock, and fares rising year on year
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The opportunities to get a decent job, buy a house, and enjoy all the city has to offer are becoming fewer
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The reality is becoming detached from the dream
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: These problems arise not because of growing demand alone but because of the failure of political leaders to respond to it
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Londoners have a right to expect more from their mayor than the 17,000 new homes that were built in the capital last year
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: - less than a third of the 63,000 a year that are needed to solve the city's housing crisis
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: That Boris Johnson has missed his own affordable housing targets in every year of his mayoralty is an abject failure of political leadership
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The government's unwillingness to commit to vital transport infrastructure, such as Crossrail 2 and new Thames bridges, is scarcely better
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: History shows us what can be achieved when politicians take population growth seriously and rise to the challenges it creates
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: In the midst of the second world war, even as bombs fell and the city burned, a plan was devised to respond to London's growth
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The Abercrombie plan, officially called the Greater London plan, laid out an ambitious vision for a new postwar London: decent housing replacing slums, efficient transport, full employment, new parks and open spaces
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: It was a radical and comprehensive document that provided the detail for rebuilding London after the devastation of the war
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: New towns including Stevenage and Crawley were built in the south-east
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: modern transport infrastructure, including the north and south circular roads, was planned to cope with the increasing number of cars
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: The requirements of a successful London were drawn up and implemented
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: A growing population and new pressures on services mean we need a new, equally ambitious plan today
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Empty words about more homes and better jobs will not cut it
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: they are no substitute for a serious and detailed proposal for building at least 63,000 homes a year and rebalancing the city's economy to create jobs and opportunities for Londoners while continuing to invest in the industries of tomorrow
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The city's creaking transport system must be upgraded, with Crossrail 2 and other new infrastructure built
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: This must happen without the continuous and excessive raising of fares
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: which burns holes in Londoners' pockets
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Keeping London affordable for ordinary people must be central to the plan, and improving the quality of life of Londoners a core theme
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Given that London successfully adapted to growing demands in the middle of a world war, we can be optimistic about our chances of doing the same today
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: We should not let those with a political agenda use London's growing population to support their anti-immigration rhetoric
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: we should challenge those who want to label London's global attraction a flaw rather than a strength
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: That our capital is back at its peak population is a sign of its success as a great global city
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: People from all corners of the globe still take great risks, at great expense, to become Londoners and to benefit from the city's opportunities
paragraphs.label: common-ground

paragraphs.text: But this isn't a time for complacency
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Whoever the next mayor is, they must focus their gaze on solving the problems that stem from growing demand on London's infrastructure
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: As
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: population continues towards 10 million
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: we need a new plan to take London forward together according to the qualities of the city at its best
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: inclusive, diverse, ambitious, forward-looking and offering a wealth of opportunities to all who live here
paragraphs.label: assumption
